lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Properties are a powerful tool we rely on heavily when working with React.

If some properties aren’t provided and we don’t handle this case, we may get unexpected output, like an empty element.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If a property is not provided, nothing will be rendered.

Try to render the property level that the parent component is not providing to the Profile component.

Make sure to pick props, followed by ., and finally level.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we try to print a non-existing property, it will print undefined.

Undefined values inside JSX don't render. React just doesn't show anything.

Make sure to pick console.log followed by ( and then props.level, ), ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use conditional rendering to show only the whole element or section if the property is provided.

Use an embedded expression with conditional rendering to avoid rendering a broken UI if level is not provided.

Make sure to pick { followed by props.level and then &&, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To handle not provided props gracefully, we can set a fallback directly in the JSX using a ternary operator.

Code the inline if-else to render level if it was provided. Otherwise, render "Unranked" as default value.

Make sure to pick ? followed by props.level and then :, "Unranked".

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What content will be rendered in the following Profile component for the badge property?

NoneUndefinedLevel BadgeError

Make sure to pick None.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Check if rank is provided and render it as Newbie if it's not provided.

Make sure to pick props.rank followed by ? and then props.rank, :, "Newbie".

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
If a property is not provided, what does React render in its place inside a JSX expression?

An empty stringError0Null

An empty string.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use conditional rendering to display the status prop only if it exists.

Make sure to pick props.status followed by && and then {, props.status, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do you expect to happen if a non-existing prop is used in a JSX expression without any condition or default value?

Nothing is renderedA runtime error occurs'undefined' is printedThe application crashes

Nothing is rendered.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a default value when title isn't passed to the component, ensuring it shows Rookie by default.

Make sure to pick ?, followed by :, and finally "Rookie".

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following approaches is best for preventing React from rendering undefined for non-existing props?

Use default values or conditional renderingAllow React to render undefinedCatch every prop error manuallyAvoid using props altogether

Use default values or conditional rendering.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the following code output if props are not provided?

Hello, !Hello, null!The code throws an errorHello, undefined!

Hello, !.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
When properties aren’t provided, default values ensure components still display correctly, providing a reliable fallback.

Let’s look at a cleaner, more efficient way to set and use default values.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
A neat way to set default properties and keep the JS clean is to use object destructuring.

Make sure to pick {, followed by name, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We assign a default value inside {} that will be taken if no property will be passed with that name.

Set "Guest" as the default property for name.

Make sure to pick name, followed by =, and finally "Guest".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can set default values for every single property we expect.

Whenever a value is provided, it will be used. If we don't receive one, the default value will be the fallback.

Make sure to pick room, followed by =, and finally "Standard".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
No matter where we destruct the properties, we can set default values.

Set the default values "Guest" for name and "Standard" for room.

Make sure to pick name followed by = and then =, "Standard".

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Apply object destructuring to extract properties with default values.

Make sure to pick type followed by = and then "Smartphone", = "Generic".

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the default value of type in the following React component?

ElectronicsDeviceUndefinedGeneric

Make sure to pick Electronics.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set a default value for the property theme.

Make sure to pick { followed by theme and then =, "Dark Mode", }.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement correctly shows how to set a default value for language in a JavaScript object destructuring?

{ language = "English" }language = { "English" };[language = "English"]{ English = "language" }

{ language = "English" }.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use destructuring to provide default values.

Make sure to pick firstName followed by = and then "John", firstName.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Destructure and set fitting default properties for all properties.

Make sure to pick temperature followed by "20°C" and then =, "Clear".

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens if you destructure an object property with a default value, but the same property is supplied?

The supplied property value will override the defaultAn error will occurThe default property value will be usedBoth values will be displayed

The supplied property value will override the default.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is correct for assigning a default value to a prop in a functional component?

const Component = ({ propName = "default" }) => {...}const Component = (props.propName = "default") => {...}const Component (props) ==> { props.propName = "default"; ... }const Component = (props) => { propName:"default", ... }

const Component = ({ propName = "default" }) => {...}.
